quote: Station log.  Stardate 46910.1.  Chief    O'Brien has the sad duty of escorting    his wife back to earth to attend her    mother's funeral.  For the next few    weeks, it will up to the rest of us    to keep this station up and running.
It's almost as though the re-   filtration processors were waiting    for Chief O'Brien to leave before    breaking down...
The technology looks like something    the Cardassians might have taken    from the Romulans...       Is that an R-C-L type one matrix    field?
(bored, trying to be     clever)   Perhaps we ought to call in a Romulan    repair service...
Or is it an R-C-L type two...
Another raktajino?
(still studying, no     eye contact)   It would keep me up all night.
I know better ways to keep you up    all night... and they're more fun    than drinking Klingon coffee...
Definitely type one...
Dax.
I really should be getting to bed.
May I escort you to your quarters...
That's not necessary, Julian.
Oh, goodnight then...
... "Not necessary, Julian"...       ... But not forbidden, either.
Dax.
Yes... ?
You are Dax...
What do you want?
Yes, Major.
I'm just not sure, Commander.  What's    it look like to you?
It looks like a residual charge in    the graviton generator.  If that's    what it is, it'll bleed off.  Let's    run a quick level three diagnostic,    just to be sure.
Bashir... to Ops...
Ops.
... Three people... I think they just    took Jadzia.  She was struggling    with them, and I tried to help, but...    I don't know, I'm...
scene: 21   INT. CORRIDOR ONE - INTERCUT WITH OPS (AS DESIRED)

quote: Full station security alert; secure    all Turbolifts; seal off airlocks to    levels four through twelve...    Computer, locate Lieutenant Dax.
scene: 21   INT. CORRIDOR ONE - INTERCUT WITH OPS (AS DESIRED)

quote: Lieutenant Dax is on Level Six,    Corridor One.
scene: 21   INT. CORRIDOR ONE - INTERCUT WITH OPS (AS DESIRED)

quote: No, that's where I am... They only    left her combadge here...
scene: 21   INT. CORRIDOR ONE - INTERCUT WITH OPS (AS DESIRED)

quote: How long ago, Doctor?
scene: 21   INT. CORRIDOR ONE - INTERCUT WITH OPS (AS DESIRED)

quote: Not long, uh... I'm... not quite    sure, really.
scene: 21   INT. CORRIDOR ONE - INTERCUT WITH OPS (AS DESIRED)

quote: Computer: Display all passages, levels    four through twelve; in sequence.
scene: 21   INT. CORRIDOR ONE - INTERCUT WITH OPS (AS DESIRED)

quote: What... what are you doing?
We turn right at the next corridor...
They're managing to avoid the security    tracking grid.  They seem to know a    lot about the station.
Then they may know the speed of our    Runabouts... if they do, they probably    have a faster ship to make their    escape...
Major, survey all ships in dock that    have a high warp capability.    (Beat; sudden     realization)   Damn!
What.
That's why we've got a residual charge    in the graviton generator.  They've    disabled the tractor beam.
We've got eight ships in dock that're    capable of warp five or more: Three    on docking pylons; five smaller ones    in the ports.
Seal off all docking ring airlocks.
Security.  All duty squads to the    docking ring; commence immediate    inward sweep, levels sixteen through    twenty-one.
I've got them!  Airlock five...
I'm on my way.  Odo to Security.     Report to airlock corridor five.  We    have a hostage situation.
Isolating with cadderon force fields.       ... Commander?
You're doing fine, Major.
Will you just tell me what you...
Move.
The force field is down... They know    the security override codes... They're    boarding a ship...
I'm trying to speed up the bleed-off    process in the graviton generator.
We've lost them...
It's working.  I'm increasing the    flow to the EPS wave guides.
The excess charge is neutralizing...
Engage tractor beam!
Gotcha.
Bring it in to docking port six,    Major.
Slowly!  Extremities where I can see    them.
You're the Chief of security?
Are you all right?
My name is Ilon Tandro...
... Special envoy from Klaestron    Four... I'm in charge of this    extradition procedure...
Extradition!  I call this kidnapping    and assault.
You'll find this to be a valid warrant    for her arrest.  The relevant treaty    between Klaestron Four and your    Federation allows for unilateral    extradition.
And the charge?
The fugitive Dax is charged with    treason... and the murder of my    father.
According to the charge statement,    Dax was responsible for the death of    General Ardelon Tandro thirty years    ago...
Thirty years ago?  That would've    been Curzon Dax.
... when he was on Klaestron Four as    a Federation mediator during their    civil war...
He never mentioned he'd even been to    "Klaestron Four"... Strange.
Not so strange considering these    charges.
Odo, let me tell you something: Curzon    Dax tended to be a little cavalier    about life... and even about his    personal responsibilities from time    to time...
... I think part of the reason I liked    him so much was that he had more    faults than the usual, socially    acceptable Trill.       He was not a murderer.
How about a "traitor"?       This says Dax betrayed the Klaestron    government to the rebels.
It's all nonsense.  I'm telling you,    Constable, I knew the man.
But did you know the symbiont inside    the man?
Come in.
I've sent a subspace message    to Klaestron Four requesting    confirmation of the warrant.  That's    the only stall I could think of.     Now what the hell's going on, Dax?
Dax, if I'm going to help you, you've    got to help me.
I don't expect help, Benjamin.  Thank    you, though.

Are you crazy?  Treason and murder.     On Klaestron Four, either of those    gets you the death penalty.       What's the matter with you!  Talk to    me before I have to let these people    take you.
No.  I'm sorry, Benjamin, but... no.
We've got eighteen or twenty years    of friendship behind us.
I'm Jadzia Dax now.  It was Curzon    Dax you knew for twenty years.
So when the Dax part of you survived    from one host to the next, it really    didn't take our friendship along.
Benjamin, you know you're still my    very dear friend.  I just... won't    talk about this; I'm sorry.
Well, whether you're Curzon Dax or    Jadzia Dax, I'm not going to believe    for one second that you've ever    committed murder, or treason.
(reflexively starts     to explain)   Benjamin...       ... If you don't mind... I'd prefer    being alone right now.
There is one thing I'd charge you    with...    (stops; faces her for     emphasis)   ... Acute stubbornness.
You've received your confirmation,    Commander; now we'd like to be on    our way with the prisoner.
You know, Mister Tandro... I kept    wondering why you tried to kidnap    Lieutenant Dax, rather than just    present your warrant to me in the    proper way.  I couldn't figure that    out at first.
I trust you have figured out,    Commander, that our extradition treaty    with your Federation is current and    valid.
This station is technically Bajoran.
(already knows the     answer)   What does that mean to us?
You don't have an extradition treaty    with Bajor.  I think that's why you    tried to abduct Lieutenant Dax.  You    were afraid the Bajorans would refuse    extradition.
That's absurd.  No Bajoran interests    are even involved here.
How did you people know your way    around this station so well?
My conversation is with the Commander.
No, I think your conversation is    with my First Officer now.

You Klaestrons are allies of the    Cardassians.  Your knowledge of this    station confirms that.  They must    have given you the layout... Which    not only compromises Bajoran security,    but also... annoys us.
I'm afraid it means Bajoran interests    are involved.  And Bajor is adamant    that...
(courteous aside to     Kira)   ... At least I believe it's adamant...
Oh, yes...
You see... There will have to be an    extradition hearing before I can    lawfully release Lieutenant Dax.
For how long?
As long as it takes.
That could be days!
There's nowhere else on the station    that's suitable.
Too bad.  I'm not shutting down for    any Bajoran hearing...
I'm sure Lieutenant Dax would    appreciate it...
Business is business.
You know, that wall's going to have    to come in about five meters...
What are you talking about?
Of course, after you move the wall    that'll mean your second level    holosuites'll have to come down...
Come down?  Why?
New restrictions...
Restrictions?
Building codes... Since the    provisional government took over,    they've got their hands into    everything... and of course, I'm the    one who's expected to enforce their    rules here.
You know, I think the bar is a little    too near the exit...
This is blackmail...
No, it's just business... And business    is business...
I was just coming to see you.  We    still haven't found any place for    the hearing.  Holding it on Bajor    would involve Dax leaving the station,    and I don't want to risk that.
Well, now that's a coincidence.  Our    good friend Quark just donated the    use of his facility for the hearing.
Nice gesture.
I thought so.
You know I haven't been able to get    a word out of Dax about any of this.
So I thought someone might go do    some investigating on Klaestron Four    itself.  What do you think?
This case has thirty years of dust    covering it.  The extradition    hearing'll take about thirty minutes.
I'm hoping to make it a little longer    than that.
Good luck.

This will be an informal hearing, so    I'll start with some informal advice    to all:  I'm one hundred years old.     I've no time to squander listening    to superfluous language.  In short,    I intend being here until supper,    not senility.  Understood?
scene: 53   INT. QUARK'S - E.C.U. ON RENORA'S FACE

quote: Understood, Madame Arbiter.
scene: 53   INT. QUARK'S - E.C.U. ON RENORA'S FACE

quote: You seek the extradition... Make    your case.
scene: 53   INT. QUARK'S - E.C.U. ON RENORA'S FACE

quote: The accused Trill, whatever its    present appearance may be, was and    is a Federation officer who committed    capital crimes on our planet.  Since    there is no time limit on the    prosecution of such crimes...
scene: 53   INT. QUARK'S - E.C.U. ON RENORA'S FACE

quote: Thank you, I've already read the    warrant and charges.  The crimes    described are thirty years old.     What took you so long?
scene: 53   INT. QUARK'S - E.C.U. ON RENORA'S FACE

quote: The evidence was contained in military    files which were officially sealed    until recently.
scene: 53   INT. QUARK'S - E.C.U. ON RENORA'S FACE

quote: Fine.  Sit.  Commander, the warrant's    in order.  On what grounds do you    ask me to deny extradition?
scene: 53   INT. QUARK'S - E.C.U. ON RENORA'S FACE

quote: You say the warrant's in order.  But    the name on the warrant is "Dax."     Certainly that doesn't refer to Jadzia    Dax, a female; but to the now deceased    Curzon Dax, a male.       ... This young woman wasn't even born    thirty years ago.
scene: 53   INT. QUARK'S - E.C.U. ON RENORA'S FACE

quote: You're arguing semantics.  This    creature is a Trill.  The symboint    known as Dax has progressed from one    host to the next.
scene: 53   INT. QUARK'S - E.C.U. ON RENORA'S FACE

quote: Exactly.  From one host to the next.     A different host; a different person.     So I submit that the person he wants    to extradite no longer exists.  And    I challenge him to prove otherwise.
scene: 53   INT. QUARK'S - E.C.U. ON RENORA'S FACE

quote: That's ridiculous.
scene: 53   INT. QUARK'S - E.C.U. ON RENORA'S FACE

quote: It would've been easier on me had    you not raised that point, Commander.       But the penalty for these crimes on    your planet is death; and that's    rather permanent.  So before I grant    extradition, you will convince me,    please, that the person named in    your warrant is the same person that's    sitting here now.
scene: 53   INT. QUARK'S - E.C.U. ON RENORA'S FACE

quote: Station log, Stardate 46440.2.  The    extradition hearing will reconvene    at oh-nine-hundred hours.  Lieutenant    Dax still remains silent regarding    the  charges against her.
She doesn't seem to care whether she    gets out of this or not.

I care.  Doctor, we've given the    opposition access to our computers    and station library, such as it is...    so let's utilize them ourselves.  I    want all the medical evidence you    can find to support the theory that    Jadzia Dax and Curzon Dax are two    entirely separate people.  Major...
Excuse me, Sir.  I don't know that    there is any medical evidence on    that.

Assume there is, then find it.    Major... I'm not asking you to be an    attorney here, but... If you'd check    the Federation computers for any    precedents... legal decisions    involving Trills...
(reciting; being sure     she's got it right)   Is a Trill responsible for the    conduct... for the acts...
of it's antecedent selves.  What if    I find the answer's "yes"?
Then that answer's wrong.  From this    minute on, our answer is "no."       ... But if you do find a... "wrong"    answer, I want to see it.  I can't    fight what I don't know about.
Commander, aren't we a little out of    our depth here?
We're fighting for her life, Major    Kira.
I understand that.  I don't understand    why she won't help us fight.
Commander Sisko.  There is a subspace    communication from Odo on Klaestron    Four.
We've only got a few hours, people.
Constable... What've you got for us?
You mean it's not over?  You stopped    the extradition?
Just a delaying action; it's all I    could do.  I'm still hoping you'll    find something there on the planet    that'll negate the charges.

Well, I know two things so far:    Whoever did murder this General    Ardelon Tandro, it got his troops so    mad they went out and won their civil    war.  They made the General a national    martyr.  There are statues of him    all over the place.  Second:  everyone    that's old enough to remember says    the General and Curzon Dax were the    closest of friends... Comrades;    inseparable.
Now that sounds like the Curzon Dax    I knew.
Treason, plus the murder of his own    best friend?  Strange business.  If    those charges are true, I'd want to    hang Curzon Dax up by the heels    myself.
Thanks for the confidence.

Don't worry, I'll do my job.  General    Tandro left a widow.  If the two men    were that close, she has to remember    something about Curzon Dax that's    not in the record.  You'll hear from    me.
Curzon Dax was not responsible for    the death of my husband.
scene: 59   INT. ENINA TANDRO'S MAIN ROOM (KLAESTRON FOUR)

quote: (reacts to the     surprising new ally)   You're certain of that?

quote: Without a doubt.
scene: 59   INT. ENINA TANDRO'S MAIN ROOM (KLAESTRON FOUR)

quote: But your own son...
scene: 59   INT. ENINA TANDRO'S MAIN ROOM (KLAESTRON FOUR)

quote: My son is obsessed with the death of    a father he never knew... I tried to    persuade him not to reopen the case.     He wouldn't listen to anyone... least    of all to me.       You have to understand -- Curzon Dax    was closer to the General than any    man on this planet.  He was a dear    friend to this family.  Curzon would    have died himself before conspiring    against my husband.
scene: 59   INT. ENINA TANDRO'S MAIN ROOM (KLAESTRON FOUR)

quote: Is that a personal opinion... or are    there any facts that might support...

quote: It might help my people to know what    they are...
scene: 59   INT. ENINA TANDRO'S MAIN ROOM (KLAESTRON FOUR)

quote: There's proof of a secret transmission    that was sent from military    headquarters to the enemy camp.  It    identified the exact route my husband    was taking from the capitol back to    the front.  That's when he was    ambushed and kidnapped... a short    time later, he was killed.
scene: 59   INT. ENINA TANDRO'S MAIN ROOM (KLAESTRON FOUR)

quote: There were only five people including    my husband who knew the route.  My    son's been able to establish the    whereabouts of all of them at the    time of the transmission... all of    them except Curzon.
scene: 59   INT. ENINA TANDRO'S MAIN ROOM (KLAESTRON FOUR)

quote: So, Dax has no alibi.

quote: That can't possibly be enough to    convict him, can it?
scene: 59   INT. ENINA TANDRO'S MAIN ROOM (KLAESTRON FOUR)

quote: I don't know.       Thank you.  You've been helpful.
scene: 59   INT. ENINA TANDRO'S MAIN ROOM (KLAESTRON FOUR)

quote: How is he?

quote: Ma'am?

quote: Curzon Dax.
scene: 59   INT. ENINA TANDRO'S MAIN ROOM (KLAESTRON FOUR)

quote: He's gone.       The Dax your son is trying to    extradite is "Jadzia Dax"; a twenty-   eight year old woman.  Curzon Dax    died two years ago.  Jadzia's the    new host.
scene: 59   INT. ENINA TANDRO'S MAIN ROOM (KLAESTRON FOUR)

quote: (reacts but covers     well)   I'm sorry.  I didn't... know.
scene: 59   INT. ENINA TANDRO'S MAIN ROOM (KLAESTRON FOUR)

quote: Odds are four to one against    her.       And let me say that's very fair.

quote: Now that's a brave wager.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: I call on the expert knowledge of    another Trill... Selin Peers...
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: Minister Peers, we're fortunate to    have you with us...
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: Excuse me.  It also seems rather    convenient to have you with us.  How    do you come to be here?
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: Because another Trill is involved,    the Trillian government requested    that I be present during the    extradition.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: And do you know the accused    personally?
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: I do not.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: We'll accept you as an expert on    Trills.  Proceed.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: Minister, through how many hosts    have you survived?
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: The symbiont within me has survived    through the adult lifetimes of seven    hosts.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: Do you remember your very first host?
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: Of course.  It was a woman, as a    matter of fact.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: Do you remember what you thought and    felt when you were joined with your    first host?
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: Yes; the symbiont does carry memories    of times shared with previous hosts.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: So if a crime is committed by a Trill,    then the symbiont's next host would    remain aware of it... would recall    that crime?
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: Yes, absolutely.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: Would recall the details of it.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: Yes, absolutely.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: And would still feel the guilt of    it.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: Oh yes.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: Madame Arbiter, this is not a trial...    and Mister Tandro is not the    prosecutor...
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: You've made your point, Mister Tandro.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: I don't believe I have, Madame    Arbiter.  The real point is that    Commander Sisko would have you endorse    his idea of a perfect Trill crime...    to commit it, all one has to do is    elude capture long enough to change    hosts, then he... or she can go free.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: Minister Peers... You said you were    with your first host throughout her    "adult" life.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: Yes...
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: So before a symbiont is joined with    any host, that host has already lived    a significant portion of his or her    life.  From birth to... what age,    sir?
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: Early-to-mid-twenties.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: Why not younger?
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: To give the prospective host the    chance to develop; mature... They    have to be old enough to make an    informed judgement as to whether or    not they really want to be joined.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: And once they are joined, the host's    personality is completely suppressed    by the symbiont?
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: Oh, no.  No, it's a joining.  It's a    total sharing, a blending, of both    host and symbiont.  Neither is    suppressed by the other.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: So with each new host there does    come, in fact, a new personality.  A    new combined person.  A different    person.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: From that standpoint, yes.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: Well I for one don't know what other    standpoint we could be talking about,    thank you, Minister.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: Just to return us to what's important    here, Madame Arbiter... the accused    can remember any crimes she committed    as Curzon Dax and nothing can be    truthfully asserted in this hearing    that can alter that fact.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: Yes, the memories were passed to an    entirely new host... to an entirely    different person...
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: This is outrageous... you can't let    Dax get away with murder.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: I said an "informal" hearing; not    riotous.  We'll have a two hour    recess.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: Still nothing to say?
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: Just "thank you."  I know you're    trying very hard.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: I didn't mean that.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: I know.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: Your silence makes you look guilty.     At least deny something.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: Benjamin... why don't you just stop    this...
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: ... Leave it alone.  Leave me alone.
scene: 60   INT. QUARK'S - ON QUARK, MORN & FERENGI WAITER

quote: The answer seems simple enough to me --    split her down the middle.  Send the    symbiont back for trial and leave    the host here.
I'm afraid it's a bit more complicated    than that.
Oh, what a surprise.  Please enlighten    me.
The symbiont and the host are    biologically interdependent.  Ninety-   three hours after they've joined,    neither can survive without the other.
I see.  Proceed, Commander.
Doctor, you've heard the arguments.     From a medical viewpoint, are Curzon    Dax and Jadzia Dax the same person...
Obviously not.  Aside from the gender    change, there's a marked difference    in blood types; metabolisms; nervous    systems, height, weight...
This is not at all relevant...
(determined to get     his testimony out)   What is relevant, sir... is my    analysis of the brain waves of Curzon    and Jadzia Dax...
Madame Arbiter...
As you can see, they are distinctly    different... clearly illustrating    that Curzon and Jadzia are two unique    individuals.
Thank-you, Doctor.
Doctor, I've looked through your    research myself... it's quite    impressive work for such a young    man...
Thank you.
As a layman, there are obviously things    I don't fully understand...
I'll be happy to explain anything    you wish...
Yes... well, exactly how does the    Trill brain work...
It's quite complex actually... First    of all, there are two cerebral    nuclei...
Two... ?
One in the symbiont and one in the    host...
Two brains.  And these two brains    talk to each other... ?
(acknowledges,     searching for a     comparison)   Like two computers linked together...
That's very clear, Doctor.  Thank    you.  Now, in your investigation,    were you able to analyze the separate    wave patterns from each of these    brains?
(the one question he     didn't want to hear)   They don't function separately.
I didn't ask you how they function,    Doctor Bashir.  I asked if you could    analyze the two distinct patterns.
I just don't see the relevance of...
Could you?
Yes.
And have the brainwave patterns of    the symbiont changed since it joined    with the new host?
With the available evidence, there's    no way to tell that.
What's your best guess?
I wouldn't care to guess.
In fact, is there evidence of any    change at all in the symbiont since    it joined with this new host?  Yes    or no.
No.
Thank-you, Doctor Bashir.  You've    been very helpful.
Any more witnesses, Commander Sisko?
Yes, Madame Arbiter... I'd like to    call the one person in this courtroom    who knew Curzon Dax.  Me.
You know where the witness chair is.
With your permission, Major Kira    will direct the questions.
Tell us a little about Curzon Dax,    Commander.
He probably wasn't the ideal Trill.     He drank a little too much; he could    be more interested in women than    maybe he should've been...
I thought he was your friend.
My point is simply that he was not    at all like the young woman in this    courtroom.
What exactly was your relationship    with Curzon Dax?

He took a raw, young Ensign under    his wing and taught me to appreciate    life in ways I'd never thought about    before... he taught me about art and    science and diplomacy... whatever    sense of honor I may have today, he    nurtured... treason, murder -- he    wasn't capable of those things.
As you've already said, Commander,    this is not a trial...

I'm describing my friend, Curzon Dax --    a man I knew very well. On the other    hand...       I can't tell you too much about my    new friend there... We're really    just getting to know each other.
Commander, Starfleet officers do    have the reputation of being    honorable... and I judge you to be    an honorable man...
As an honorable man, do you think    this crime should go unpunished?
Madame Arbiter, that has nothing to    do with the main issue here.
It will, Madame...
Answer the question, Commander...
I would prefer that no crime go    unpunished.
Then, if it were possible, even you    would not argue with punishing the    symbiont part of Dax.

How can you be so sure that the    symbiont was the criminal influence?     What if it were the "Curzon" host    that was responsible?  Then, the    surviving symbiont would be completely    innocent.

No; they'd both be guilty.  You    yourself have argued that the two    personalities, once joined, function    as one.  And your own Doctor Bashir    confirmed it.  When you put salt in    water, the two become    indistinguishable and inseparable.
Sorry, but that Tandro's very good.     Odds are now thirteen to one against    her.

(still to Tandro;     pleased)   I think you've just made my point    for me.  When the water boils off,    the salt returns to its original    state.  Pour that same salt into    another liquid, and you have something    completely different.  Jadzia Dax is    an entirely new entity.
Oh.  Well... six to one might be all    right.
Following a one hour recess...
Lieutenant Dax will take the witness    chair.       One hour.
If you won't defend yourself, you're    not going to testify.
It's a hearing, not a trial.  She    has no choice.
(continuing, re: the     PADD, to Sisko)   Odo's on subspace... It's urgent.
I've made some progress.
Good.

Not good.       Since the transmission to the enemy    is the key evidence, I thought it    might be a good idea to go through    all the communications logs from    headquarters during that period... I    even found Curzon Dax's records...
You can't tell me Curzon would log    in a communique to the enemy...
No.  Nothing like that.  But the log    shows a number of conversations    between Dax's office and General    Tandro's home.
They were close friends.
Many of the conversations took place    when the General was away at the    front.
The wife.
The wife.
Curzon Dax and Enina Tandro...

Maybe it was innocent.  Maybe he was    just providing a little emotional    support during tough times.       Or... maybe they were taking advantage    of the General's absence to get a    little closer.  If they were having    an affair, that translates into a    pretty solid motive for murder.
The conversations were just the    beginning... I've also found records    of gifts... of holidays spent at an    Inn outside the capital...
What purpose is this supposed to    serve?
It serves the truth.
The truth.
If there's more to this than meets    the eye, I hope you'll explain,    because as it stands, this will    severely hurt Dax's defense.

My husband wasn't nearly the hero in    life that he was in death, Mister    Odo.  In death he became a legend.     And I became a legend's wife.  There    are people who never knew my husband    who still contact me.  Decades after    his death, they still mourn him.
But you don't.

No.  You see, I knew the man before    he became the legend.       But I also knew my place in history.     I was to carry on bravely, never to    remarry.  I was to represent my    husband at the banquets held in his    name.  And of course, never to speak    of who he really was... because nobody    wants to hear that.
They may have to hear it now.
No matter what's said, they'll still    embrace his memory... for he was and    will always be the hero who died for    his people.       But perhaps it is time for my place    in history to change.

You've been protecting her reputation.     That's it, isn't it... that's why    you won't even defend yourself...       There are worse things than an illicit    love affair.  Curzon Dax didn't murder    anybody.  He didn't commit treason.     Are you really willing to commit    suicide over something done in another    lifetime?  That is what you're doing,    you know.
My God, Dax... young Tandro... he    wouldn't be your son...
(shakes her head,     almost funny)   Benjamin, you have an overactive    imagination...
Then what is it that's holding you    back?  Help me.
Dammit, if you were still a man...
I see your temper hasn't improved...
Don't talk to me about my temper...
Curzon always warned you about it...
You're not going to get me off track    here...
Do you remember that Argosian    lieutenant who threw a drink in your    face...
... And you knocked me down with a    right cross before I could kill him...    I still have a little scar here from    your ring finger...
I tried that ring on after Curzon    died... it slipped right off my    finger...
If you don't help me, old man, they're    going to take you... because I don't    know any more arguments.
Then allow it to happen.
I have an obligation to protect the    lives of those in my command.  You    ought to know that.  You taught it    to me.
That was Curzon.
I'll stop trying to protect you the    minute you tell me Curzon was guilty    of these charges.

I won't discuss it with you and I    won't discuss it in the witness chair.     As for Enina Tandro, yes, I feel the    shame for Curzon's indiscretions.     When one of my kind stumbles,    Benjamin... it's a mistake that's    there forever.  I can't tell you    which part of Curzon Dax couldn't    stop himself from acting shamefully    with another man's wife.  I can tell    you he did love her, for whatever    that's worth.
Enough to kill her husband?
So you are starting to question.
What else can I do?
Nothing, Benjamin.  Nothing at all.

Lieutenant Dax... You're either two    hundred years older than I am... or    you're about the same age as my great    granddaughter.  At first I wondered    which of those you were.  Now I'm    bothered by the likelihood that you're    both.       Let's finish, please.  Commander?
At what age did the host, Jadzia,    first want to be joined as a Trill?
I wanted it since I was a child.  I    worked very hard for it.
The competition to become a Trill is    very strong, then, among potential    hosts.
Oh, yes.  It's considered a great    honor.
And how did young Jadzia finally    become a host candidate?
By winning scholarships... competing    against other young people.  You're    tested in countless ways.
Including psychological tests; to    determine the strength of character    of the prospective host.  Is that    true?
Yes.
And the young Jadzia excelled in    those tests of academics and    character... of psychological    stability.
Yes.
If you can remember other things...    Remember that as well.
What academic degrees do you hold,    Lieutenant?
I have Premier Distinctions in    exobiology, zoology, astrophysics    and exoarchaeology.
How many of those degrees did you    earn before you were joined with the    symbiont Dax?
All of them.

All of them.  As Jadzia;  Alone.  A    brilliant and independent young woman    who's done nothing in her life but    contribute to her society.       Madame Arbiter, how can anyone justify    trying her for a crime allegedly    committed by another entity before    she was even born?
This will only take a minute.     Lieutenant... As a Trill candidate,    did Jadzia fully understand the    responsibilities to be assumed upon    becoming a Trill?
Yes.
Did you willingly accept those    responsibilities, and whatever    consequences they might entail?
Yes.
And would that not obviously include    the consequences of criminal acts    committed by Curzon Dax?
May I speak?
Mother?
And you are?
I am Enina Tandro... Widow of General    Ardelon Tandro.       This hearing is unnecessary.  The    accusations are... erroneous.
What are you talking about?

Madame Arbiter, Curzon Dax is accused    of having made a transmission to the    enemy that betrayed my husband.  But    I know where Curzon was at the exact    time that transmission was made.       He was in my bed... with me.
Mister Tandro, I think you'll want    to re-examine your extradition    request.  Until then... this hearing    is adjourned.
Calm yourselves; all bets'll be    paid... An orderly line, please...
You were kind to try and protect    me... someone you never even met...
scene: 98   INT. PROMENADE SECOND LEVEL - FAVORING DAX & ENINA

quote: There's much of Curzon that's still    a part of me.  That still remembers    what you had together.
scene: 98   INT. PROMENADE SECOND LEVEL - FAVORING DAX & ENINA

quote: But it was Curzon Dax who swore    himself to silence to preserve the    memory of General Tandro... Not    Jadzia.
scene: 98   INT. PROMENADE SECOND LEVEL - FAVORING DAX & ENINA

quote: I felt it was important to keep that    promise.  The General's memory is    cherished by your people...
scene: 98   INT. PROMENADE SECOND LEVEL - FAVORING DAX & ENINA

quote: And it will continue to be.  No one    will ever know he was the one who    tried to betray us... and that the    rebels killed him for the favor.       As for you, I ask only one further    kindness...
scene: 98   INT. PROMENADE SECOND LEVEL - FAVORING DAX & ENINA

quote: Of course.
scene: 98   INT. PROMENADE SECOND LEVEL - FAVORING DAX & ENINA

quote: Live, Jadzia Dax.  Live a long, and    fresh and wonderful life.
scene: 98   INT. PROMENADE SECOND LEVEL - FAVORING DAX & ENINA

quote: Are you all right?
Yes.  As a matter of fact, I think I    am.       Don't I recall your offering to escort    me safely home?
That was four days ago.
Was there a time limit?
Hardly.
